case.name: Grant v Monitor Money Corporation Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1716 (8 December 2006)

application for certificate. federal proceedings (costs) act 1981 , s. 10(3). practice and procedure
hearing fixed to commence on a particular date but no judge available

federal proceedings (costs) act 1981 (cth), s 10(3)(a). a hearing which has been fixed to commence on a particular date but which does not do so because no judge of the court is available to hear it, has been "discontinued" within the meaning of s 10(3)(a) of the federal proceedings (costs) act 1981 (cth). hearing sydney, 1985, june 24-27. 27:6:1985
evidence of loss exceeding estimate admitted at trial without objection
verdict based on loss exceeding estimation in particulars

contract to carry out excavations for rail authority
contractor working three shifts seven days per week
injunction granted to third party restraining contractor from working at certain times
whether implied term of contract that authority would grant reasonable extension of time and indemnify contractor against additional costs occasioned by grant of injunction
jurisdiction to entertain claim that contract frustrated
power to award interest on award
allegation of misleading or deceptive conduct
motion to strike out statement of claim

federal court of australia rules, o. 20, r. 2; o. 4, rr. 1, 2; o. 11, r. 16; o. 12; o. 19. the applicant's statement of claim alleged misleading and deceptive conduct by the respondents in breach of s. 52 (1) of the trade practices act 1974 (cth.). the respondents applied to have the statement of claim struck out, mainly on the basis that it did not disclose a reasonable cause of action. it was argued that the statement of claim did not plead any material facts which could form the basis of a claim under s. 52.

citances.sentence: In that regard, it may be noted that in many cases, the time and expense involved in the consideration and resolution of an interlocutory dispute is entirely disproportionate to its significance to the just and effective resolution of the case as a whole by mediation or trial: see Youlden Enterprises Pty Ltd v Heath Solutions (WA) Pty Ltd [2006] WASC 161 ; (2006) 33 WAR 1 (at [2]) per Martin CJ. Australian Courts in more recent times have taken a restrictive attitude towards interlocutory skirmishes in general and strike out applications in particular: see Grant v Monitor Money Corporation Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1716 per Siopis J (at [14]---[17] and [73]).
